raw_text:
Ferguson urges Henry punishment
 
 Sir Alex Ferguson has called on the Football Association to punish Arsenal's Thierry Henry for an incident involving Gabriel Heinze.
 
 Ferguson believes Henry deliberately caught Heinze on the head with his knee during United's controversial win. The United boss said it was worse than Ruud van Nistelrooy's foul on Ashley Cole for which he got a three-game ban. "We shall present it to the FA and see what they do. The tackle on Heinze was terrible," he said. Clubs are permitted to ask the FA to examine specific incidents but information is expected to be provided within 48 hours of the game. The clash occurred moments before half-time when a Freddie Ljungberg challenge left Heinze on the ground on the left touchline. Henry, following the ball, attempted to hurdle the Argentine but his knee collided with the back of Heinze's head.
 
 The striker protested his innocence - and referee Mike Riley deemed the collision accidental. Ferguson was also upset by Arsenal's overall discipline during the heated encounter between the two arch-rivals and praised his own side's behaviour. "Edu produced a terrible tackle on Scholes that was a potential leg-breaker," he said. "There were 24 fouls in the game by Arsenal, seven on Heinze, five on Ronaldo, six by Vieira - and it was only his sixth foul that got him booked. Phil Neville got booked for his first challenge. "I am proud of my players for the way they handled that pressure. "We have always been good at being gracious in defeat. What happened on Sunday overshadowed our achievement, but then they do it all the time, don't they?"
llama3.2:1b: Sir Alex Ferguson calls for punishment of Thierry Henry for an incident involving Gabriel Heinze during Arsenal's win over Manchester United.
Ferguson believes the tackle was deliberate and Henry protested his innocence.
The incident occurred before half-time and resulted in a red card for Henry.
Ferguson praises Manchester United's behavior, which he describes as "good" under pressure.

Henry protested his innocence, while referee Mike Riley deemed the collision accidental.

Ferguson stated that they would present the case to the Football Association (FA) within 48 hours of the game.
The clash occurred moments before half-time when a referee named Freddie Ljungberg made a decision.
Henry protested his innocence and the incident was deemed accidental.
Arsenal's overall discipline during the match against United was praised, with Phil Neville getting a warning for being booked for his first challenge.
They are proud to be gracious in defeat.

The game occurred moments before half-time when a Freddie Ljungberg challenge left Heinze on the ground on the left touchline.
He attempted to hurdle the Argentine but his knee collided with the back of Heinze's head, resulting in a terrible tackle.
Arsenal's overall disciplined during this heated encounter between the two arch-rivals has earned it.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the original text.
It does not include explanations or justifications for the actions taken by the players or the FA's decision-making process.
The focus remains on the events themselves, without providing additional context or analysis.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Ferguson has called on the Football Association to punish Arsenal's Thierry Henry for catching Gabriel Heinze with his knee during United's controversial win in 2015.
The tackle was described as terrible, worse than Ruud van Nistelrooy's incident involving Ashley Cole.
The collision occurred before half-time and involved a Freddie Ljungberg challenge on the ground by Henry after the ball.
The FA will investigate this matter within 48 hours.
Meanwhile, Arsenal players are commended for their discipline in handling the situation, while players criticized for being insensitive were fined.
tinyllama:1.1b: Sir Alex Ferguson has called for Arsenal captain Thierry Henry to be punished for his reckless tackle on defender Gabriel Heinze during the match between Manchester United and Arsenal in October 2004.
Ferguson believes that Henry deliberately tackled Heinze, worse than Ruud van Nistelrooij's challenge against Ashley Cole, which earned the former player three games' suspension.
The incident occurred during a chaotic period of the game when Arsenal had 24 fouls and seven bookings, and Ferguson criticized his players' behavior.
However, he also praised Arsenal's overall disciplinary performance as well as their refusal to give in to the heat of the game.
Overall, Ferguson is satisfied with Arsenal's handling of the situation and emphasizes that it was not only Henry's sixth tackle on Heinze that caused the incident, but also his behavior.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Sir Alex Ferguson has urged Arsenal to punish Thierry Henry for a reckless tackle that led to Ashley Cole receiving a red card and United securing victory in the match.
Ferguson stated that Henry's aggressive action was worse than Ruud van Nistelrooy's foul on Ashley Cole during the 2005 FA Cup final, which resulted in a three-match ban for the Dutch defender.
Henry's tackle left Arsenal midfielder Gabriel Heinze with a swelling head after he tried to challenge Thierry.
Ferguson said that clubs should be allowed to review specific incidents and expect information within 48 hours of the game, while referee Mike Riley deemed Henry's tackle accidental.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Sir Alex Ferguson has urged the Football Association (FA) to penalize Arsenal's Thierry Henry for a tackle that struck Gabriel Heinze on the head during a United-Arsenal match.
Ferguson argues this incident was more severe than Ruud van Nistelrooy's infamous foul, which resulted in a three-game ban.
The tackle occurred near half-time when Henry attempted to clear Heinze but his knee made contact with the Argentine's head after a Freddie Ljungberg challenge.
Despite protests of innocence and referee Mike Riley's classification as accidental, Ferguson emphasized the severity of the incident.
The United manager also criticized Arsenal's overall discipline, citing 24 fouls, seven on Heinze, and five on Raymond Verheyen (Ronaldo).
In contrast, he praised his team's behavior, noting only six fouls for Phil Neville and graciousness in defeat despite the intense match.
